metadata.title: Cleft Lip and Palate
anatomical location body part affected: Lip, palate, velum, and uvula may be affected
description: Cleft lip and palate are birth defects in which the lip and/or palate does not form normally in utero, resulting in an opening in the lip and/or palate. Most children with oral clefts are identified prenatally by ultrasound or at birth and might present with cleft lip only, cleft lip and palate, or cleft palate only.(1,2) A submucous cleft of the palate refers to cases in which the cleft is covered by mucous membrane. These clefts are difficult to see when looking in the mouth and are usually diagnosed by touch. Clefts occur in approximately 1 in 700 births with variability related to geographical region, socioeconomic status, and ethnicity.(3) Unilateral cleft lip or palate is more common than bilateral cleft lip or palate(4)

749.2.749.20: cleft palate with cleft lip, unspecified

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement have been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Children with clefts of the secondary palate (hard palate, soft palate, and uvula) often present with delayed acquisition of sounds that require palate and velar function (e.g., stops and fricatives). As a result, they might produce compensatory sounds in the form of glottal stops, pharyngeal stops, and pharyngeal fricatives. In addition, children with clefts of the secondary palate often have delayed expressive language development and concomitant difficulties such as conductive hearing loss due to fluctuating middle ear disease (otitis media)(1) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: Findings of research studies indicate that 70% of cleft lip and palate cases and 50% of cleft palate–only  cases occur inisolation (“nonsyndromic” or “isolated”)

Syndromic cases can be divided into chromosomal syndromes, teratogenic syndromes, and uncategorized syndromes.Teratogenic syndromes are caused by exposures to substances such as phenytoin, valproic acid, and thalidomide, andprenatal exposure to environmental toxins such as maternal drug, alcohol, or cigarette use, vitamin A (e.g., Accutane),herbicides, and increased altitude(2,3)

The presence of a syndrome might increase the risk of other developmental difficulties (e.g., cognition/cognitive delay) thatmight affect communication(6)–Children with Pierre Robin sequence often have cleft palates(2,7) (for detailed information about assessment and treatmentof children with Pierre Robin sequence, see Clinical Review… Feeding Disorders: Infants with Pierre Robin Sequence ;Topic ID Number: T708984)–Velocardiofacial syndrome is a genetic disorder resulting in cleft palate(8)
risk factors :: Risk factors include exposure to the teratogens mentioned above and genetic predisposition(3,10)

In a study conducted in Brazil with 40 mothers of children with orofacial clefts and 40 mothers of children withoutorofacial clefts, researchers found that the presence of an orofacial cleft was associated with low consumption of folate,low intake of folic acid during the preconception phase and first trimester, and lack of family planning(77)
Family history of clefts is associated with increased risk of cleft in future pregnancies when more than one family memberhas a cleft(4,10)

overall contraindications precautions: Due to the unique speech, language, and feeding problems in patients with cleft lip and/or palate, speech-language pathologists (SLPs) will benefit from graduate, postgraduate, or continuing education training specifically related to assessment and treatment of patients with cleft lip and/or palate(11)

A child born with a cleft should be assessed soon after birth by a craniofacial team of professionals that includes a plastic surgeon, an orthodontist, an SLP, and at least one specialist from the following areas: otolaryngology, audiology, pediatrics, genetics, social work, psychology, and dentistry. This team should meet regularly to determine pre- and postsurgical treatment plans(1)

Etiology of cleft lip and palate should always be considered during assessment and treatment. Patients with clefts of syndromic origin might be medically fragile or have accompanying issues that affect prognosis. Children with cleft lip and palate sometimes have increased oral sensitivity due to surgeries and medical management
Be aware of and consider cultural views and differences regarding the appearance and cause(s) of cleft lip and/or palate

contraindications precautions to examina: Swallow examination –Feeding assessment : Complete a full assessment of the patient’s feeding and swallowing skills(17)  -Supplemental feeding via a nasogastric tube may be necessary in infants and children with cleft lip and/or palate who experience weight loss or insufficient weight gain due to feeding difficulties and/or post palatoplasty(17,34) -For detailed information about feeding assessment for patients with cleft palate, see Clinical Review…Feeding Disorders: Infants with Cleft Lip and Palate , referenced above as well as series of Clinical Reviews on dysphagia

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -Is there a cleft lip, palate, or both? Unilateral or bilateral? -When was the cleft lip and/or palate diagnosed? -Diagnosis of cleft lip may be made antenatally via ultrasound(9,12) -Most diagnoses of cleft lip and/or palate will be made immediately postnatally(12) -Isolated cleft palate might be missed in a newborn examination as the baby’s external appearance is normal; in this case, the diagnosis is often made following feeding difficulties soon after birth(12) -For detailed information about feeding and swallowing disorders that occur in infants with cleft palate, see ClinicalInfants with Cleft Lip and Palate ; Topic ID Number Clinical Reviews on dysphagia assessment -Submucous clefts might not be identified until later in infancy or during the preschool years during work-up  for feeding problems or hypernasal speech -Is there an underlying medical condition associated with the cleft lip and/or palate?

course of treatment.medical management: Depending on the time of assessment and age of the patient, a medical history might include questions about previous surgical interventions A procedure to repair a cleft palate is referred to as a palatoplasty(13) The cleft lip is often repaired in one procedure at the age of 10 weeks. However, a two-stage  procedure is required if the cleft lip is wide or bilateral.(3) In this case, the first surgery for the lip adhesion typically takes place around 6 weeks of age. The lip adhesion brings the two lip segments together temporarily and is followed by a final lip repair at 3 months of age. Pressure equalization tubes might be inserted at 3 months of age due to the high risk of middle ear pathology in children with cleft palate The authors of a prospective, randomized clinical trial conducted in Denmark found that the timing of the hard palate closure in a twostage  procedure influenced early language development(14) Closure of the residual cleft prior to 12 months of age resulted in the best speech and language outcomes, especially with respect to phonological development(14) In a study conducted in Sweden, researchers found that early closure was associated with better speech outcomes than late closure by comparing consonant production in 28 children born with unilateral complete cleft lip using transcriptions of audio recordings taken at 18 months and 3 years of age. The outcome measures used for comparison were the percent correct consonants adjusted for age (PCCA),  number of established phonemes, and phonological simplification processes at age 3 years;these were compared to consonant inventory at 18 months. The researchers compared the outcomes in speech and phonology in the children with cleft lip and palate according to the methodtwostage closed (TSC; twostage  early hard palate closure, mean age of 12.3 months at surgery, n = 9), two-stage  open (TSO; twostage  late hard palate closure, mean age of 36.2 months at surgery, n = 9), or one-stage  closed (OSC; onestage palatal closure, mean age at surgery 13.6 months, n = 10). Taking into consideration all of the above outcome measures, the best speech/phonology outcomes at age 3 were associated with the OSC group, and the worst outcomes were associated with the TSO group. Overall, there were not significant differences in outcomes at 3 years for the OSC or TSC; however, the outcomes were significantly worse for the TSO group, indicating that early closure (around 12 months of age) should be recommended for the best possible speech outcomes(68) The primary palate repair typically occurs around 12 months(1) and most often before the age of 2 years(15) For patients who have not had cleft palate repair prior to the age of 10 years, late repair will not result in normal speech patterns; however, some improvement in speech sounds can be expected(15) During preschool years, about 20% of children require additional surgery (pharyngeal flap or sphincter pharyngoplasty) to compensate for velopharyngeal insufficiency (VPI)(4)T708864 Additional common surgeries include alveolar bone grafting, surgery of the lip and nose to correct deficiencies, or orthognathic surgery for children with skeletal defects affecting the facial profile(4)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed : Usual tests for this condition include the following:
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has had speech, occupational, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of speech, language, and swallowing symptoms
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night -Drooling and airway obstruction can affect sleep patterns
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient is experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., excessive drooling, difficulty hearing or breathing)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Note respiratory status; patients with cleft lip and/or palate might require supplemental oxygen or tracheostomy tubes due to an underlying syndrome related to cleft lip and/or palate(7,16) -Infants with Pierre Robin sequence and cleft palate are at increased risk of respiratory distress from upper airway obstruction(17)Note psychosocial status; inquire about symptoms of depression and anxiety on the part of the patient and/or parent(s)/caregiver; refer to psychiatric professional for intervention as appropriate -Patients with cleft palate are at increased risk for social anxiety and major depressive disorder(18) -In a study conducted in the United States with 279 children with oral clefts ages 4 to 9, researchers found that these children were at increased risk for separation anxiety disorder as compared to the general child population. In those children with speech or eating problems related to the oral cleft, the risk for separation anxiety disorder more than doubled(64) -Low self-esteem  and poor self-image  can result from peer reactions to the appearance or speech of a patient with cleft lip and/or palate(19) -Researchers in Sweden examined untrained listeners’ perceptions of the speech of a group of subjects with cleft palate; not only were the untrained listeners able to detect hypernasality and nasal emission, these characteristics were also perceived negatively by these listeners(20) -Parents and families of children with cleft palate might require psychosocial support before and after the birth of the child due to anxiety about the child’s appearance and surgical needs as well as the stress associated with early feeding difficulties.(61) A child’s psychosocial adjustment is affected by maternal psychological health(7,21,22)For children with cleft palate, annual hearing evaluations are recommended to rule out hearing loss as a result of fluctuating middle ear disease.(4) Children with cleft palate have increased risk for conductive hearing loss resulting from otitis media, cholesteatoma, and outer ear malformations(76,78,80) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _______________________

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient or parents/caregiver about other problems, including feeding difficulties and academic or behavioral problems The findings of several studies have indicated abnormal cerebellar volumes in children with nonsyndromic cleft lip and palate; these researchers suggest that abnormal brain and facial development might play a role in cooccurring deficits seen in children and adults with cleft lip and palate(23)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient or parents/caregiver about other symptoms the patient is experiencingQuestions should establish the parents’/caregiver’s level of concern and their socialemotional reaction to the child’s condition. In addition, a communication history should identify the language(s) spoken at home, in  the community and/or at school by the child and/or caregivers. Depending on patient’s age at time of assessment, parental/ caregiver questions about communication should determine when he or she reached any communication milestones (e.g., babbling, first words, twoword combinations, responsiveness to social interaction) In a study conducted in the United States with 15 children with nonsyndromic cleft lips and/or palates ages 17 to 34 months, researchers examined the rate of development of communicative acts, canonical vocalizations, and words as Young children with cleft lip and/or palate exhibited significant increases in the rate of communicative acts between ages 17 and 34 months progressing from babbling to word use.(66) When compared to the rates of communicative acts of typically developing children and those with developmental delay, the children with cleft lip and/or palate fell between these two groups indicating that there are some early delays in the rates of developing early communicative behaviors even in the presence of ageappropriate  performance on cognitive measures(66) Pre-linguistic  rates of canonical babbling were comparable to those of typically developing children(66) Rates of word use as the children transitioned from pre-linguistic  to linguistic level were not as high as those of typically developing children, but were not as low as those of children with developmental delay(66) The children with cleft lip and/or palate in the study who had low rates of word use had higher rates of gesture use indicating that these children used gestures to communicate when insufficient vocabulary or poor speech intelligibility limited expressive ability(66)

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: -Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any -Is the patient currently in daycare, preschool, or school? -Is the patient employed? -Is a communication deficit interfering with the patient’s ability to perform academic, vocational, or avocational tasks?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document use of assistive or adaptive equipment, including mobility aids and augmentative or alternative communication (AAC) devicesTo determine the quality and quantity of the patient's opportunities to communicate, obtain information regarding the child’s living environment (e.g., number of siblings and level of caregiver involvement, language[s] used in the home) and educational environment

relevant tests and measures.general: It is recommended that assessment of the patient with the cleft lip and/or palate be conducted ›Relevant tests and measures : It is recommended that assessment of the patient with the cleft lip and/or palate be conducted collaboratively by the craniofacial team.(1) Some instrumental procedures used by the SLP may include specialized equipment such as a nasometer, endoscope, nasopharyngoscope, or videofluoroscope.(4) When feasible, it is recommended that a combination of perceptual and instrumental procedures be used during evaluation due to poor interrater reliability for hypernasality.(25) Exact procedures will vary with the medical history, compliance, and age of the patient. Assessment of speech and language abilities should be highly individualized and include examination of connected speech production, especially for older children and adults with persistent speech impairments related to cleft lip and/or palate(62)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: muscleA flexible endoscope can be used to view the VP port from above. When possible (e.g., when the patient is able to tolerate insertion of the endoscope), nasendoscopy is preferable to videofluoroscopy because it does not involve radiation(32)Videofluoroscopy in the lateral view is recommended to evaluate VP function during connected speech. Sentences with nonnasal consonants should be included in the evaluation. The velum should be maintained in an elevated position with firm contact against the VP wall. Production of words with nasal consonants should also be introduced to see if the velum can be alternately elevated and lowered without fatigue of the VP musculature(32) -In some cases, if a fistula has been identified, it is necessary to instill barium into the nasal passages during videofluoroscopy and have the patient swallow in order to determine if there is a functional connection through the palate. A lateral view and frontal view examination should be performed(32)In the absence of videofluoroscopy or nasendoscopy, obtain a lateral view x-ray  of the patient’s head as the patient produces a sustained nonnasal consonant (e.g., /s/) to evaluate the ability of the velum to elevate during the production of nonnasal consonants. The velum should elevate and make firm contact against the posterior pharyngeal wall. A gap may indicate that the velum is not elevating properly(32)Nasometry reveals a nasalance score (the percentage of nasal output relative to total output) and has been used increasingly in clinical and research settings. The patient reads a passage without nasal consonants (e.g., “Zoo” passage) while speaking into the nasometer. Cut-off  scores indicating the presence of abnormal hypernasality range from
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Speech and language examination (including reading) –Speech -Evaluation of articulation -Patients with cleft palate often have difficulty producing alveolar consonants or exhibit alveolar backing (sounds that should be produced in the front of the mouth [e.g., /t/ or /d/] are produced with the tongue in the back of the mouth).(60,63) Individuals with cleft palate exhibit both articulation and phonological errors even after surgery for palatal closure.(71) For detailed information about speech sound disorders common in individuals with cleft palate, seeArticulation Disorders, Organic ; Topic Number IDPhonological ; Topic Number ID -Speech sampling -Naming tasks(26) -Samples of sentence and syllable repetition are recommended to allow for control of phonetic content and to provide a method for collecting similar samples on a longitudinal basis(27)  -Obtain a connected speech sample by recording the patient reading or using spontaneous speech -Complete a phonetic error analysis to determine the nature and source of sound errors (e.g., nasal sounds are substituted for nonnasal consonants)(28) -Infants with cleft palates with or without cleft lips have less complex cry melodies and variation in cry rhythmicity(29)Determine the contexts in which the speaker can successfully produce correct sounds –Language -Language samples and the appropriate standardized language tests should be used to assess language if language delay is suspected(5) -In a study conducted in the United States, researchers compared the language and early reading skills of children with nonsyndromic cleft lip and/or palate to those of age-matched,  typically developing children; no significant difference was noted in verbal language skills at ages 5 and 7 years; children with a cleft scored significantly higher in early reading skills at age 7(30) -For detailed information on childhood language disorders, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topicAssess fluency of speech and stuttering if there are concerns –Voice -V ocal quality should be examined for unusual habitual pitch, breathiness, harshness, or reduced loudness. Hoarseness is common in children with cleft palate.(75) V ocal nodules occur frequently, likely as a result of habitual hard glottal attack in the presence of compensatory articulations or the need for increased effort to achieve greater intensity(74) -Assess prosody in connected speech; abnormal prosodic contours have been described in case studies of individuals with cleft palate(62) –Reading -Literacy problems are common among children with cleft lip and palate.(31,73) If age appropriate, assess reading ability using a standardized test (e.g., the Test of Early Reading Ability) or refer the child to a reading specialist at his or her school. Children aged 4-6 years with cleft lip and palate are at increased risk for reading delays compared to children without cleft lip and palate. The severity of the cleft is associated with the degree of reading delay.(31) Children with cleft lip and palate are at increased risk for verbal memory and phonological awareness deficits, which can lead to impairments of spelling ability(73)
relevant tests and measures.oral structure and oral motor function: Oral structure and oral motor functionNoninstrumental proceduresIf age appropriate, have the child count from 60 to 80 and produce multiple productions of the followingpuppy, house, push, jelly, peach, goat, zebra, chocolate chip cookies, “the big black dog caught the stick”, and “I like strawberry pop”.(24) Perceptual descriptions of hypernasality are usually documented by rating scales -Audible nasal air emission accompanying stop consonants(20,81) -Weak stop consonant production(81) -Substitutions of nasal consonants for nonnasal consonants(81)Obtain a connected speech sample by recording the patient reading or using spontaneous speech. Judge speech intelligibility, resonance distortion, and voice deviation -Observations of anatomical structure -Shine a flashlight on the VP region while the patient tilts head back and opens mouth wide. Determine the following1) normal palatal mucosal covering, 2) evidence of a velar cleft, 3) normal left/right velar symmetry, 4) left side velar atrophy, 5) right side velar atrophy, 6) bilateral atrophy or short velum, 7) tissue swelling or scarring, 8) tissue redness, 9) swollen tonsils, 10) lesions or growths, 11) bifid uvula(24) -For submucous clefts, the SLP will sometimes feel a notch or depression in the hard palate when the palate is palpated with a gloved finger; submucous cleft palates are often associated with a bifid uvula -Submucous cleft of the soft palate is associated with a midline deficiency of the velum or reduced muscle tissue/ abnormal positioning of the velar tissues -Submucous cleft of the hard palate is characterized by a bony defect in the midline of the hard palate Have the patient open mouth wide and say /a/ for as long as possible while shining a flashlight in the mouth to illuminate the VP. Observe for midline symmetry, velar elevation and retraction, velar deviation to the left or right, and limited or no velar motion bilaterally. Listen for hypernasality(24)Place a small mirror (e.g., dental mirror) under the patient’s nostrils and observe if the mirror fogs during production of words with nonnasal  consonants (e.g., /p, t, k, b, d, g, s, z/). Mirror fogging is Normal nasal air omission can occur at the onset and offset of the word or a sentence(32)Have the patient produce nonnasal words while pinching the nostrils and without pinching the nostrils. There should be no change in the perceived quality of the words during both conditions. If there is a quality change in word production with the nostrils pinched and open, this might indicate that the VP port is open(32)instrumental procedures of the VP opening, the exact movements of the velum and pharyngeal walls, and the function of the levator veli palatini

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

The use of blowing and other nonspeech oral motor exercises to strengthen VP function and improve speech outcomes in individuals with cleft lip and palate is not supported in the research literature.(70) Despite widespread use, they are not believed to improve speech production for the following reasons: 1) they lack relevancy (i.e., the patient is producing speech); 2) oral structures move and function in different ways during speech and nonspeech tasks; 3) there is no evidence to show that these movements strengthen oral musculature; and 4) there is no evidence that increased oral awareness improves speech production(70)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: If a patient with a cleft presents with feeding, articulation, VPI, and/or language difficulties, and/or if the parents or patient require education regarding feeding or speech and/or language strategies, involvement of an SLP is necessary treatment _ _ Treatment for glottal stops _ _ Electropalatography (EPG) _ _ See Treatment summary , aboveExpected progression will depend on the type and severity of the compensatory articulationsImplement a home program to reduce CAD as appropriate for each unique child Velopharyngeal impairment (VPI) (also known as VP insufficiency, incompetency, dysfunction) _ _ V oice deviations and vocal fold abnormalities due to prolonged use of incorrect hard glottal attack strategies to compensate for volume deficiency due to VPI(24)Reduce escape of air through the nose due to insufficient VP closure or VPITherapeutic strategies _ Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) _ _ Visual feedback _ _ Speech-aid prosthesis _ _ See Treatment summary , aboveExpected progression will depend on the child’s goals related to correcting VPIImplement a home program to reduce VPI as appropriate for each unique child  Social anxiety(18) Reduce social anxiety while increasing speech-language abilityHolistic paradigm _ Therapy focusing on cognitive, emotional, and psychosocial dimensions of communication(58) _ _ _ Refer to a social worker/clinical psychologist as appropriate _Expected progression will depend on the child’s goals related to social anxietyImplement a home program to address social anxiety specific to the needs of the child Recurrent otitis media and conductive hearing loss: inadequate function of the palatal muscles may cause eustachian tube dysfunction leading to persistent middle ear effusion and possible conductive hearing loss(4)Reduce occurrence and severity of otitis mediaTherapeutic strategies _ Refer to audiologist. Many children require tympanostomy tube placement, and periodic hearing tests are essential(4)N/A N/A Language delay associated with cleft palatePromote language developmentTherapeutic strategies _ Naturalistic language therapy _ _ See Treatment summary , aboveExpected progression will depend on the child’s goals related to language delayImplement a home program in collaboration with the parents as appropriate for each unique child Deformed, supernumerary, or absent teeth(59)Reduce effects of dental abnormalitiesDental referral _ Refer to dentist and/or prosthodontistN/A N/A Feeding difficulties related to cleft palateAssist caregivers in providing nourishment to the infant with a cleftTherapeutic strategies _ Feeding therapy as indicated. _ See Clinical Review… Feeding Disorders: Cleft Lip and Palate , referenced above _ _ See Treatment summary , aboveExpected progression will depend on feeding goalsImplement a home program in collaboration with the parents/caregivers as appropriate for each unique child .
assessment plan of care.rule out: Differential diagnosis by a pediatrician or genetics specialist should be used to identify if the cleft is a feature of a syndrome
prognosis: In a study of clinical outcomes in the United Kingdom, researchers reported that following cleft palate repair and speech therapy over half of 5-year-olds  (n = 238) and almost 20% of 12-year-olds  (n = 218) had residual articulation difficulties suggesting the need for additional postsurgical speech treatment(35)

Researchers in China conducted a study of early language development in Chinese-speaking  children aged 8 to 15 months with unrepaired cleft palates and noted no delay of language comprehension for those children younger than 14 months; however, expressive language delays were noted for the children 14 and 15 months of age with unrepaired cleft palate(36) –The authors of this study suggested that these delays may be related to the specific phonetic characteristics of the Chinese dialect these children spoke, Putonghua (standard Mandarin Chinese)(36)
Reduced teacher expectations for children with cleft palate have also been documented, placing the child at risk for poor school performance and academic underachievement(37)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Multidisciplinary team care is associated with the best outcomes for patients with orofacial clefts(38) Referral to a geneticist for genetic testing to determine if a syndrome is the cause of the cleft lip and/or palate(39) Referral to an audiologist/otolaryngologist for identification and management of middle ear infections/conductive hearing loss and insertion of pressure equalization tubes if appropriate(39) Referral to a dentist and/or orthodontist for management of tooth misalignment and palatal prosthesis/obturator if necessary and appropriate(39,40,41) Referral to a psychologist or social worker for psychosocial support and intervention(1,19) Referral to a lactation consultant for assistance with breastfeeding, as appropriate
treatment summary: According to the Parameters for Evaluation and Treatment of Patients with Cleft Lip/Palate or Other Craniofacial Anomalies published by the American Cleft Palate-Craniofacial  Association, guidelines for speech-language  pathology services are as follows: –All patients and families should be educated regarding normal speech and language development and seen for an assessment of pre-linguistic speech-language  development by 6 months of age(67) –In cases where development of speech and language is found to be delayed or disordered, an early intervention program should be started focusing on speech sound development, language stimulation, and establishing a home program(67) –Speech-language  evaluations should be conducted twice a year for the first 2 years of life and annually thereafter to ensure that speech and language are developing adequately. After age 6, screening should take place annually until adenoid involution occurs and then every 2 years until dental/skeletal maturity is reached(67) -For children with cleft lip and/or palate who exhibit deficits in speech-language  development or VPI, reevaluations should occur as often as deemed necessary by the patient’s interdisciplinary treatment team(67) -Speech evaluations are essential pre and posttreatment to determine candidacy for and outcomes of medical, surgical, and behavioral interventions and should always include a perceptual assessment of articulation, resonance, and voice(67) -Instrumental evaluations of VP function are necessary for patients with resonance disorders and/or audible nasal air emission; when vocal quality is abnormal, the larynx should be directly visualized before initiation of voice therapy(67) –Biofeedback therapy might be effective for some patients with VP dysfunction; however, blowing exercises and oral-motor  therapy are not(67)

Feeding/nutrition : If the child’s cleft involves only the lip or the lip and alveolus, feeding difficulties are usually minimal. When clefts involve the palate, the opening between the nose and mouth makes it more difficult for the infant to produce negative pressure and achieve effective sucking.(4) The SLP should provide information to the team or the parents to assist the newborn with feeding. Other professionals such as the nurse, occupational therapist, and nutritionist may also provide feeding support. Some specialists have recommended the use of a palatal obturator to cover the palatal opening during feeding. This can be made by a dentist and used soon after birth. However, most children with cleft lip/palate do not require an obturator for successful feeding(4) –The following suggestions for feeding are recommended by the Cleft Palate Foundation:(42) -Place the infant in an upright position so that gravity will help prevent milk from coming through the baby’s nose(42) -Formula/breast milk may come out of the baby’s nose during feedings; however, this does not mean he or she is choking; attempt to alleviate this by keeping the baby more upright(42) -Watch for a pattern of sucking and swallowing – listen for a swallow followed by a breath; most babies will develop a pattern within a few days after birth(42) -Infants with cleft palate should be given time to feed and should be burped regularly since they tend to swallow a lot of air during feedings. Eventually, feeding time should be no more than 30 minutes for 2-3ounces(42) -Mothers who are unable to nurse but would like to make breast milk available to the infant can use a variety of bottles designed to assist with feeding. If a specialized bottle is not immediately available for infants receiving pumped breast milk or formula, a squeezable bottle can be used with a larger x-shaped  hole cut in an orthodontic or preemie nipple(42) -The following are types of specialized bottles that are manufactured for infants with cleft palate: Mead Johnson’s Cleft Palate Nurser, Medela’s Haberman Feeder, and Children’s Medical Venture’s Pigeon Bottle(42) –Whenever possible, experts recommend using the mother’s preferred feeding method (i.e., breast or bottle)(42) –For detailed information about feeding therapy for patients with cleft palate, see Clinical Review…Feeding Disorders: Infants with Cleft Lip and Palate , referenced above

Early communicative attempts : Parents should be encouraged to respond to all sounds made by the child because greater parental responsiveness encourages more babbling. Increased babbling might lead to better gains in speech development after palate repair(1) –Studies examining parent and peer preferences suggest that compensatory babbling patterns are preferred over ones that are excessively hypernasal, suggesting that parents may be unintentionally reinforcing compensatory patterns in speech that are difficult to later remediate. Thus, it is recommended to respond to all sound attempts, regardless of the quality of sound used to increase vocalizations. Parents should be instructed on the undesirability of compensatory speech patterns. There are currently no studies regarding the effectiveness of promoting babbling in infants with cleft palate –There have only been a few,very small studies investigating the effects of “naturalistic” intervention specifically with children with cleft palate.(43,44)This type of intervention promotes the use of naturalistic intervention models to promote functional speech and language development(1,72) –There is no evidence that palatal obturators enhance consonant development during babbling for babies with unrepaired cleft palate(45)

Hypernasality/VPI : VPI might result from lack of contact between the soft palate and pharyngeal wall due to length, weakness, stiffness (e.g., due to scar tissue), or postsurgical tethering of the velum.(24) Another reason for VPI is a palatal opening (fistulae). When VPI is present, it tends to worsen with fatigue. Speech therapy is reportedly successful in correcting VPI in a majority of patients with mild hypernasality, but some children need additional palatal surgery or a prosthesis to correct more moderate or severe symptoms.(4,24) Studies examining the efficacy of behavioral treatment for VPI are limited. There is no support for the use of nonspeech tasks such as blowing, sucking, or swallowing to increase VP function –Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) -Positive airway pressure is delivered to the nasal passage via a mask to provide progressive resistance against which the VP musculature must function when a hypernasal person is speaking. By functioning against progressive resistance, it is hypothesized that the VP musculature will strengthen -Forty-three  subjects participated in a single group study conducted in the United States that examined the effectiveness of an 8-week  (6 days a week, 10-24  minutes), home-based  CPAP regimen. Results indicated variability among participant response, with some achieving decreased hypernasality. Further research is needed to confirm the efficacy of CPAP for VPI and hypernasality(46) –Visual feedback -Several studies (conducted in Germany and Mexico) have used nasopharyngoscopy to provide biofeedback to the patient about VP function during speech.(47,48,49) These studies have had promising results, but the nasopharyngoscopic endoscope required for feedback is invasive (inserted in through the nares) and are often not available in the clinical setting -Less invasive feedback measures such as a See-Scape  can be used to provide visual feedback for self-monitoring  of oral/nasal airflow while the patient produces words that include nonnasal sounds. VP strengthening methods have been described, such as using a See-Scape  with blowing exercises, but research documenting the effectiveness of such procedures is lacking(24) –Speech-aid  prosthesis -Speech bulbs and palatal lifts are two types of prostheses that have been used to permanently close the VP port and/or to stimulate VP movement prior to secondary surgical management.(50,51) Evidence from small research studies and case studies suggests that a prosthesis might assist with increased levator activity and improve speech intelligibility in some patients.(50,51,53) However, firm evidence regarding the effect of prostheses on VP function is lacking. Some children who are not candidates for surgery or who have had less than optimal results with surgery may also benefit from a prosthetic device.(24)When appropriate, SLPs should refer a child to a prosthodontist for an evaluation

Compensatory articulations : The most common compensatory articulations in children with cleft palate are glottal stops, pharyngeal stops, and pharyngeal fricatives.(81) There is limited research on the effects of intervention targeting articulation in children with cleft palate(1) –Focused stimulation (FS) approach -The FS approach is a naturalistic intervention based on “high-density” modeling and responsive interaction with little direct prompting.(1) Components of this approach include following the child’s lead, facilitating conversation through games/books, modeling, and expansion and responsive interaction. This approach was developed for use with children  with language delays and has most recently been applied in a study with children with repaired cleft palates. In a study conducted in the United States examining the use of parent-delivered  FS with children with compensatory articulations, researchers found that 60% of the children exhibited a reduction in glottal stop use(52) –Whole language vs. phonological treatment -In a study conducted in the United States utilizing random assignment (N = 30), researchers compared a phonologic approach (remediation of speech errors at the rule level) to the whole language approach (naturalistic language approach using play and story books with speech sounds targeted indirectly) in remediating compensatory articulation disorder (CAD) for children with repaired cleft palate ranging in age from 3 to 7 years. Intervention was delivered in small groups (2-3 children) for 1-hour sessions 2 times a week. Results indicated that the whole language approach required more time to reduce compensatory articulation errors than the phonological approach. However, the authors emphasized that children with CAD often have accompanying language delays and that it is reasonable to address CAD and linguistic targets simultaneously given limitations in time and resources(52) –Treatment for glottal stops -It is common for children with cleft palate to articulate nonnasal consonants incorrectly in the larynx by forcefully approximating the vocal folds instead of stopping the airflow in the mouth. It is recommended to treat these errors as soon as the child will tolerate behavioral treatment. The following are guidelines to assist with the elimination of glottal stops.(32) Have the child: -Exhale or sigh on the hand or mirror -Make a sustained /h/ sound -Make a sustained /h/ sound followed by a sustained vowel -Say /ahaaaaa/ -Say /hhaaapppaa/ (making a light /p/ contact) -Add other sounds and use nasal sounds (/aaammmaaa/) -Repeat with the nostrils pinched closed –Corrective babbling -Corrective babbling is a phonetic-based  speech intervention developed for children with articulation errors related to a repaired cleft palate. Corrective babbling is implemented by a child’s parent(s) or primary caregiver(s). Parents are trained in the method of corrective babbling, which involves behavioral treatments and techniques for sound stimulation, and provided with a manual. Parent(s)/caregiver(s) are asked to work with their child for 10 minutes per day and meet with the SLP regularly for follow up sessions(54) -In a study conducted in Canada with 13 children with articulation errors due to repaired cleft palate, researchers found that children who followed the program as prescribed over the course of four months made articulation improvements. In this study, participants were placed in either an immediate or delayed treatment group in order to have a control group comparison. Most of the participants did not execute the program as prescribed (i.e., 10 minutes daily), but for those that did, significant improvements in articulation were observed. Researchers could not draw firm conclusions regarding effectiveness of corrective babbling for children with cleft palate and recommended further research with larger sample sizes and longer study durations(54) –Electropalatography (EPG) -EPG includes an artificial hard palate constructed to fit against the speaker’s hard palate which is connected to a computer to provide the speaker with feedback regarding articulatory placement. The authors of single case and small group studies have reported positive outcomes with EPG to assist with palatalized and nasopharyngeal misarticulations.(55,56) Following a study conducted in Scotland examining SLPs’ views of outcomes using this method, researchers indicated that EPG is particularly useful in the “establishment phase” but that other methods should be used in addition to EPG to facilitate generalization of newly learned sounds.(56) Authors of a review of 6 studies of speech therapy for patients with cleft palate found considerable variability in methodology and outcomes; overall, this preliminary research did indicate that EPG was a promising tool for increasing the speech intelligibility of children with cleft palate. The authors of 3 of the studies found EPG resulted in faster improvements in the articulation of sounds that were resistant to conventional articulation therapy(57) –Holistic paradigm to reduce social anxiety -In a single group study conducted in the United Kingdom, researchers investigated an approach for children (8-14  years, N = 12) that focused on cognitive, emotional, and psychosocial dimensions of communication within a “supportive” 6-day  course. Results indicated positive effects on the children’s “communication and psychosocial functioning”(58)  . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Decreased communication ability for infants and toddlers with cleft palatePromote vocalizations in infants and toddlers and encourage speech and language development simultaneouslySpeech therapy _ Naturalistic intervention _ _ Palatal obturationExpected progression will depend on communication goalsA home program should be developed in collaboration with the child’s family to increase communication of the child Compensatory articulation disorder (CAD)Reduce compensatory articulations and speech errorsTherapeutic strategies _ Focused stimulation (FS) approach _ _ Whole language vs. phonological treatment _ _ Phonological treatment vs. articulation

increased age-appropriate language skil: Formal or informal assessments of language ability
increased swallowing safety: Swallow studies (e.g., bedside swallow examination, fiberoptic endoscopic evaluation of swallowing)

maintenance or prevention: Maternal avoidance of teratogens (exposures to substances such as phenytoin, valproic acid, and thalidomide and environmental exposures such as alcohol or cigarette use, vitamin A [e.g., Accutane], herbicides, and increased altitude) might reduce the risk of cleft lip and/or palate(2)
Prenatal folic acid supplementation might reduce the risk of cleft lip and/or palate(77,79)
Genetic counseling might be appropriate for families with history of cleft lip and/or palate to understand risk of craniofacial abnormalities with future pregnancies
patient education: Patient and family/caregiver education should include information on normal speech and language development as well as expected feeding and speech/language development in children with cleft lip and/or palate Parents should be trained to perform oral care following feedings to prevent infection and soreness of the lips, palate, and nasal passages(1)
Information for parents of children with cleft lip and/or palate is available from the Cleft Palate Foundation, http://www.cleftline.org/parents-individuals/
Information for parents, patients, and professionals is available from the Cleft Lip and Palate Association, https:// www.clapa.com/ Note
